title: Tension in string hold charged spheres together

content.question: Small spheres <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are attached by a <math alttext="20 centimeters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>cm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> long string. The charges on spheres <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are <math alttext="positive 2.4 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>2.4</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="positive 3.6 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>3.6</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mi>μ</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. The tension in the string holding them together is most nearly

unit.text: 8: Electric Charges, Fields, and Gauss's Law

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
